data.description:
Michael Eugene Sumpter was born on August 26, 1947 in the Boston, MA area. He was serving a 15-to-20-year sentence for another different crime committed years after the rape and murder of Ms. Britton. He died of cancer while on parole at the age of 54 in 2001. 

Sumpter was convicted of raping a stranger at her Boston apartment in 1975 and assaulting another woman he met at the MBTA’s Harvard Square Station, just blocks from Britton’s apartment. After his death, he was also linked by a DNA match to a 1985 rape in Boston.

The night of the murders, the Bernhardts had set the table for three, and when police were called to the scene two days later, they found a hamburger casserole still out. The home showed no signs of forced entry.Both Clifford and Linda had suffered blows to the head, and Linda showed signs of strangulation and sexual assault. There were also signs that both were bound at the wrists and ankles at some point, though investigators never found the bindings.
The "Golden State Killer" and "East Area Rapist"

Duke Pierson: Pierson was employed by the Spokane County Sheriff’s Office from 1959 until September 1966. Records indicate he “resigned” from the agency where he was a Detective Sergeant. He worked as the Security Manager for Rosauers where Fielding was also employed. Duke, now 85-years old, was living in Covington County, Alabama, and was married again. In April of 2018, Detective Keyser interviewed Duke at his home. During that time, Pierson denied knowing Lampson, or Fielding. He also denied ever being interviewed by Spokane County Detectives regarding Fielding's death. Pierson admitted to dating thousands of women, and if he had dated Fielding, the relationship lasted no more than a week. When asked about his familiarity with hunting/rural areas of Spokane, Duke replied, “Not really, I was hunting but not four-legged things" and laughed.

On May 4, 1986, McFadden (aka "The Animal") kidnapped 20-year-old Gena Turner, 19-year-old Bryan Boone, and 18-year-old Suzanne Harrison as they took a trip to Lake Hawkins north of Tyler. McFadden raped and strangled Harrison and dumped her body in a park about 25 miles from Lake Hawkins. She was found the next day. He was arrested on 6 May, after a police report from a couple he had attacked by the lake on the day of the murder. Three days later, the bodies of Boone and Turner were discovered, with gunshot wounds being the cause of death. McFadden had been convicted of rape three times between 1972 and 1978, but never had to serve his full sentence. He was released on parole in July 1985. There were several witnesses who had seen McFadden close to the scene of the crime on the day of the killings. Ammunition found in his possession was identified as the same ammunition used in the killings of Boone and Turner. DNA evidence was collected from the bodies at this time. On July 9, 1986, he overcame Kenneth Mayfield, a jailer, and escaped from the prison in Upshur County with Rosalie Williams, another guard, as a hostage.[4] He was arrested two days later after the biggest fugitive hunt in Texas state history. In August 1986, he was sentenced to life imprisonment for the escape. n July 1987, he was sentenced to death for the murder of 18-year-old Suzanne Harrison, 20-year-old Gina Turner and 19-year-old Bryan Boone. In October 1999, he was executed in the Huntsville Unit by lethal injection. In January 2019, Jerry was linked by GEDmatch to the July 24, 1979 murder of Anna Marie Hlavka; Anna was found dead by her sister inside her apartment, Police said Hlavka had been sexually assaulted and strangled with the electric cord from her clock radio.

Burns was arrested 39 years after the killing of Michelle Martinko using DNA evidence. The 64-year-old man charged in the 1979 stabbing death of an eastern Iowa teenager waived his right to a preliminary hearing Thursday and will plead not guilty in the killing, his lawyer said.
Holmes was identified as the killer of Christine Franke in 2001 using genetic geneology. The 38 year old Orlando native was charged 17 years after the murder.

Ewing was charged in Jefferson County District Court with murder and sexual assault in a skull-crushing attack on Patricia Louise Smith, 50, in Lakewood on Jan. 10, 1984. He is serving a 40-year sentence.

Skinner was born in Los Angeles, CA in 1952. He was 17 in 1979 and was one of a number of suspects in the killing of Vicki Bridges, a single mother, in November 1979. He was identified via DNA evidence in 1997 but was finally considered the killer on April 23, 2019. He has a criminal history.
